Title: Research 2 Locking procs
Description:
information.

Hi Everyone,

;

5 incidents of long process blocking occurred on ELKPRDSQLCLUS1 between 9 PM CST yesterday and 5 AM CST today. The chart below shows culprit processes (responsible for blocking) as thick bars and victim processes (which were blocked by culprits) as thin bars. There were 5 culprits.

All of these processes (culprits and victims) came from Microsoft Dynamics AX running on host servers ELKPRDAX1, ELKPRDAX2, and ELKPRDAX3.

In every incident, the problem was on the application side: the culprit process went idle without committing the last transaction, which resulted in the culprit holding locks on tables it had changed earlier, even through it wasn’t running any queries. This happens when the application executes BEGIN TRANSACTION, then changes data in tables through INSER/UPDATE/DELETE queries, and never executes COMMIT TRANSACTION or ROLLBACK TRANSACTION. This is a bug in the application that it allows such scenario and doesn’t have any safety process to check for such abandoned processes and terminate them (which causes a rollback and releases locks).

;

In incidents 1, 4, and 5, blocking occurred on the table [AX2009_SPARTON_PRD].[dbo].[REQPLAN] (i.e. the culprit process was holding an exclusive lock on that table while sitting idle, while victim processes were trying to access the table and were blocked).

In incidents 2 and 3, blocking occurred on the table [AX2009_SPARTON_PRD].[dbo].[SMMTRANSLOG].

;

This is an application problem that can’t be fixed from the SQL Server side. If you like, I can implement auto-killing of blocker processes after they cause this problem for a certain number of minutes, which isn’t a cure for the root cause, but a pain-killer.

;

;

Thanks,

Andrew

708-609-8783

;
